articles.headline: Inflationary Wave Changes Political Terrain for Right-Wing Populists
articles.snippet: The leaders of Turkey, Hungary and Brazil are all grappling with problems posed by the global rise in prices ahead of national elections.
articles.abstract: The leaders of Turkey, Hungary and Brazil are all grappling with problems posed by the global rise in prices ahead of national elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: To all those who would pose a challenge to Jair Bolsonaro in Brazil’s coming presidential election, including the press, the Supreme Court and liberals, the embattled right-wing leader has an answer: “Only God removes me.”
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips, Carlotta Gall, Flávia Milhorance and Benjamin Novak

articles.headline: No U.S. Troops Will Be Punished for Deadly Kabul Strike, Pentagon Chief Decides
articles.snippet: The military initially defended the strike, which killed 10 civilians including seven children, but ultimately called it a tragic mistake.
articles.abstract: The military initially defended the strike, which killed 10 civilians including seven children, but ultimately called it a tragic mistake.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — None of the military personnel involved in a botched drone strike in Kabul, Afghanistan, that killed 10 civilians will face any kind of punishment, the Pentagon said on Monday.

articles.headline: Jan. 6 Committee Recommends Contempt Charge for Meadows
articles.snippet: The panel sent a criminal contempt of Congress referral to the full House, as the extent of Mark Meadows’s role in President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the election became clearer.
articles.abstract: The panel sent a criminal contempt of Congress referral to the full House, as the extent of Mark Meadows’s role in President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the election became clearer.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mark Meadows, the last White House chief of staff for President Donald J. Trump, played a far more substantial role in plans to try to overturn the 2020 election than was previously known, and he was involved in failed efforts to get Mr. Trump to order the mob invading the Capitol on Jan. 6 to stand down, investigators for the House committee scrutinizing the attack have learned.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Jail Officer Who Led Others to Safety Is Among the 74 Killed in Tornadoes
articles.snippet: Families were mourning in several states after a swarm of tornadoes left a trail of destruction. “It’s almost crushing how it feels,” said Kentucky’s governor, Andy Beshear.
articles.abstract: Families were mourning in several states after a swarm of tornadoes left a trail of destruction. “It’s almost crushing how it feels,” said Kentucky’s governor, Andy Beshear.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAYFIELD, Ky. — Robert Daniel, a veteran corrections officer at the county jail, was keeping a watchful eye on seven inmates assigned to work at a Kentucky candle factory when the sirens went off, warning of an oncoming tornado.
articles.byline: By Edgar Sandoval, Tariro Mzezewa and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: How Beijing Influences the Influencers
articles.snippet: China’s government has supported foreign YouTubers who put a positive spin on its policies, in its latest effort to shape how the world sees it.
articles.abstract: China’s government has supported foreign YouTubers who put a positive spin on its policies, in its latest effort to shape how the world sees it.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s government has supported foreign YouTubers who put a positive spin on its policies, in its latest effort to shape how the world sees it.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Raymond Zhong, Aaron Krolik, Aliza Aufrichtig and Nailah Morgan

articles.headline: Worried About Inflation? Here’s What That May Reveal About You.
articles.snippet: Age, region, education and income all influence what people think consumer prices will be a few years from now. And that creates a policy puzzle.
articles.abstract: Age, region, education and income all influence what people think consumer prices will be a few years from now. And that creates a policy puzzle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Who is worried about inflation? Older Americans, for sure; the young, not so much.

articles.headline: Its Human Rights Record in Question, China Turns to an Old Friend
articles.snippet: The International Olympic Committee’s professed neutrality has provided coverage for Beijing, which delivers big audiences and funding in exchange.
articles.abstract: The International Olympic Committee’s professed neutrality has provided coverage for Beijing, which delivers big audiences and funding in exchange.
articles.lead_paragraph: When China’s leaders came under pressure to answer questions about the health and whereabouts of Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis star, they turned to a friendly face.

articles.headline: Sears, Struggling to Sell Goods, Markets a Valuable Asset: Real Estate
articles.snippet: Many former stores are being overhauled for new retailers, but developers are installing high-end apartments, cutting-edge classrooms and even labs at sites around the country.
articles.abstract: Many former stores are being overhauled for new retailers, but developers are installing high-end apartments, cutting-edge classrooms and even labs at sites around the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shoppers may no longer come in droves for wrenches, watches or washing machines. But Sears, the once-ubiquitous department store that has been battered by the growth of e-commerce, may have one last thing of value to market: its own buildings.

articles.headline: The Fed Meets Amid Faster Inflation and Prepares to React
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve could announce plans to cut economic support faster, and may signal 2022 rate increases, at its Dec. 14-15 meeting.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve could announce plans to cut economic support faster, and may signal 2022 rate increases, at its Dec. 14-15 meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update: The Federal Reserve said it would cut back on its bond-buying faster and that officials expected to make three interest rate increases next year.

articles.headline: How Did Turkey’s Economy Go So Wrong?
articles.snippet: Even before the pandemic, Turkey was trying to ward off financial meltdown. The crisis has accelerated as President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has doubled down on his unorthodox policies.
articles.abstract: Even before the pandemic, Turkey was trying to ward off financial meltdown. The crisis has accelerated as President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has doubled down on his unorthodox policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The signs of Turkey’s disastrous economy are all around. Long lines snake outside discounted bread kiosks. The prices of medicine, milk and toilet paper are soaring. Some gas stations have closed after exhausting their stock. Angry outbursts have erupted on the streets.
